Description: The video above shows two MIDI applications that take advantage of the Sugarcube's built in accelerometer and gyroscope. In the first application a single pixel is lit to trigger a MIDI note. When the device is tilted in various directions, the pixel moves around as if it is being affected by gravity, while at the same time triggering MIDI notes along its path. In the second application, up to four pixels bounce against an edge of the device, triggering MIDI notes on each bounce to create complex polyrhythms. The direction and speed of the bounces are dictated by the direction and angle of tilt. The height of each pixel's bounce (and subsequently, the rhythm of the composition) is controlled by the buttons. This application also features a "shake to erase" function, where shaking the device causes all the lit pixels to disappear. I've written many more applications, including a step sequencer, arpeggiator, and some more physically oriented applications like the ones I've just described. Full build documentation and more information can be found at Instructables. Arduino and MaxMSP code can be found on Github.

iframe: <iframe src="http://player.vimeo.com/video/45422593?portrait=0" width="900" height="506" frameborder="0" webkitAllowFullScreen mozallowfullscreen allowFullScreen></iframe>
Description: This controller also has the option of communicating serially with MaxMSP to control various processing-intensive audio applications.  In the video above, the device is sending button data of the form (x, y, state) to Max via a USB connection.  Max uses this data to control an audio application called "beat slicer," where an audio loop is cut up and arranged in various ways.  Then Max generates LED data (also of the form x, y, state) and sends this back over to the Sugarcube via USB.  The Arduino inside the Sugarcube processes the incoming serial data and turns on the appropriate LEDs.  This way, the device acts as a tactile MaxMSP controller

Description: An illustration of the translation of rotational motion into stepping motion.
The position of a pair of legs during 12 steps of one locomotive cycle.

Description: This device relies on IR sensing and does not function optimally around sunlight, but I found out by accident that it does some interesting things while the intensity of sunlight is changing rapidly (sunrise/sunset). Here are some experiments transforming seemingly random noise from the inputs into sound/lights. Filmed in Claremont, CA. This MaxMSP patch is called straw, it was written by Stretta. Best with headphones, more info here.
